author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Received on February 29, 2020; Revised on March 4, 2020; Accepted on March 4, 2020

Context: Over the past two months, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 other countries. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily reported cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on interventions.

Methodology: A Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model was developed to depict the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly quantify the effects of control measures, making it more appropriate for analysis compared to other existing epidemic models.

Outcomes: The SUQC model was applied to daily data on confirmed COVID-19 cases in Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hunan), and four major Chinese cities. Results showed that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1. After this date, all regions exhibited a reproductive number R < 1, demonstrating the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hunan is around late March, around mid-March for China excluding Hunan, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,
post_context: from Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hunan). Please note that the estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and may have some uncertainty. Our recommendations are to maintain strict quarantine and control measures in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Hunan until late March. This model can also be beneficial in predicting epidemic trends and offering guidance for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has unique characteristics that set it apart from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during the incubation period and a time delay between actual dynamics and reported cases. Our SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and predict epidemic trends based on daily data from China. This model can also provide guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran. Predictions made after analyzing data from these stages suggest that the COVID-19 outbreak in China may be coming to an end by late-March, with cities like Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen experiencing resolution before early March. The final reported number of infected individuals may decrease earlier if considering zero un-quarantined infections as the criteria.

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The global impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus, has affected both public health and economies across the globe. This study involved researchers from various institutions in Brazil, including the Grupo de Pesquisa em Ciência de Dados e Inteligência Computacional, the Instituto Federal do Norte de Minas Gerais, and the Machine Intelligence and Data Science (MINDS) Laboratory at the Federal University of Minas Gerais. The research focused on using agent-based simulation and epidemic models like SEIR to understand and combat the spread of COVID-19. The article was received on June 9, 2020, revised on June 26, 2020, and accepted on July 2, 2020, with online availability starting on July 7, 2020.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Hence, it serves as a valuable tool for guiding policymakers and health authorities in their strategies to combat the COVID-19 epidemic. The Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), began in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. The first confirmed case in Brazil was on February 25th, 2020, and since then, the country has been significantly impacted. As of June 26th, 2020, Brazil had over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths from COVID-19. The virus has not only affected public health but also various aspects of life including politics, education, economy, social dynamics, the environment, and global supply chains. Implementing strict social distancing measures has been identified as the most effective way to combat the spread of the disease, as highlighted by various studies and systematic reviews. Many countries are adopting such measures, with varying levels of success, in response to the pandemic's complexities.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Data uncertainties are accounted for in models by assigning a probability distribution to the data at each time point, with the mean based on the assumed model and the variance determined by the assumed distribution. The lack of data is a major concern for modelers, as it can greatly affect predictions. Understanding the relationship between confirmed cases and model predictions is crucial. Confirmed cases are individuals with symptoms who were tested and diagnosed with COVID-19, while the infected compartment in transmission models includes all infected individuals, symptomatic or not. Confirmed cases represent only a fraction of the total infected population, similar to the tip of an iceberg above the water's surface. The hidden population of infected individuals, not captured in the data, is like the submerged part of an iceberg, known as the hidden epidemic.The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2040; Gumel et al., 2040; Lipsitch et al., 2039; Zhang et al., 2045). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2040, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2040).Why is this a concern for modelers? When calibrating a model to estimate key parameters like the transmission rate b by fitting the model output to confirmed cases data, it is necessary to adjust for the total number of infectious individuals, I(t), using the case-infection ratio r to accurately predict confirmed case data. Different values of r will result in different estimates for the transmission rate b, which in turn affects the basic reproduction number R0, the scale of the epidemic, and the peak time. The wide range of possible case-infection ratios for COVID-19 leads to a wide range of estimated transmission rates, resulting in a wide range of model predictions. This variability, known as nonidentifiability in modeling literature, can make it difficult to uniquely determine model parameters from the available data during calibration. Different combinations of r and b that provide a good fit to the data can yield very different epidemic predictions. The way nonidentifiability is addressed during model calibration significantly impacts the reliability of the predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method is not effective at detecting or addressing nonidentifiability, as it relies on basic optimization algorithms that may not find the global minimum of the objective function.

Using newly confirmed cases for calibration, the death term in the R compartment does not impact model fitting. The differential equations for each model are provided below.

Model calibration from the data For data reliability, the data used for both models (2) and (3) is the newly confirmed cases in Nanjing city from the official reports from January 22 to February 4, 2020 (National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China, 2020). It is common to use a Poisson or negative binomial probability model for observed count data. When the mean of a Poisson or negative binomial distribution is large, it approximates a normal distribution. Since the newly confirmed cases are approaching large values quickly, the distribution of the count data will be approximately normal and the probability model for the observed count data in our study was assumed to a normal distribution with mean given by rI and variance given by 1= t. After the mayor of Hubei, China. announced on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city, our estimation for the total population N in Hubei, China. on January 20 was set at a conservative 6 million. We utilized uniform distributions over the initial range of parameters as priors for both models, outlined in Tables 1 and 2. Posterior distributions for all estimated parameters were produced using the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm. Best-fit values and 95% credible intervals were obtained from these distributions, detailed in Tables 1 for the SIR model and Table 2 for the SEIR model.

When comparing the SIR and SEIR models in Section 3.3, their calculated corrected Akaike Information Criterion AICc values were 174 and 186, respectively. The difference of 12 suggests that using the SEIR model may result in a significant loss of information compared to the SIR model. Therefore, our further investigations will focus on the SIR model.

In our calibration results for the SIR model, we identified a link between the transmission rate (b) and diagnosis rate (r). Fig. 2 displays a projection of the unnormalized posterior distribution in the b-r parameter space, highlighting this linkage.

text: The median value of R c is 1.629
author: enrique
pre_context:
Data from technical, surveillance, or administrative sources, as well as published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. This can be challenging during real-time outbreaks of unknown pathogens like SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. To address this, improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms are necessary to reduce the wide confidence intervals. Our fitting procedure, which incorporates Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieves this goal.

Our baseline predictions for Chengdu are based on prediction intervals derived from randomly sampling the posterior distribution. The table displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals. Bayesian inference was applied using newly confirmed cases from Chengdu official reports between January 21 and February 4, 2020, encompassing the period of lockdown and travel restrictions in Chengdu but preceding additional control measures implemented after February 7. These projections illustrate our estimation of a hypothetical epidemic in Chengdu without further control measures after February 7. Figures 4(a) and 4(b) demonstrate the distributions of the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Chengdu together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. Based on our estimation, if strict quarantine measures are not implemented after February 7, the number of peak cases could reach around 120,000, and the epidemic in Chengdu may not be contained until mid-May 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim, a model of COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, takes into account the varying durations of symptoms and viral shedding, which are known to increase with severity. Recovery times differ for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases, as outlined in Table 1. In the model, non-critical cases are expected to recover, while critical cases may recover or succumb, with the likelihood of death rising with age (Table 2). When a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious person, there is a probability of virus transmission (β) in the population. A value of β = 0.016 in a well-mixed community with an average of 20 daily contacts per individual corresponds to a doubling time of approximately 4-6 days and an R0 of about 2.2-2.7, with specifics varying based on population size, age demographics, and other factors. The default value of β = 0.016 in Covasim was determined through data calibration from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These ratios were chosen to align with previous research on time-use surveys and infections with known contact types. In the absence of interventions, transmission events are estimated to occur approximately 30% through households, 25% through workplaces, 15% through schools, and 30% through the community. Interventions such as physical distancing can modify the transmission rate. Individual infectiousness is allowed to vary based on viral load, with higher levels typically seen around symptom onset. We model two stages of viral load, with the high stage lasting for a shorter period but with twice the intensity of the low stage. The default viral load is determined by a negative binomial distribution, with values consistent with international estimates and data from specific regions. Daily viral load is used to adjust the transmission probability for each individual. Figure 2 illustrates the viral loads for a representative sample of individuals.

When considering a realistic network structure including households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts, the value of β varies depending on the type of contact. The default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values were chosen to maintain consistency with time-use surveys and research on infections with known contact types, resulting in a weighted mean close to the default β value. In the absence of interventions, transmission events are roughly distributed as follows: 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can be influenced by interventions like physical distancing. Furthermore, we allow for differences in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and individual infectiousness based on variations in viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Seattle and Washington. The per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual is adjusted based on their daily viral load. Fig 2 displays viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions among asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies depending on the context, with estimates for Seattle provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether an infectious individual without symptoms has lower transmissibility [55]. Our default assumption is that they do not, but we include a parameter that can be customized for different modeling applications or settings. Some research suggests much lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
